inscribed:
Signed and numbered in graphite of each print, verso: Bernd Becher / Hilla Becher / [sequence number, encircled]

Titled in graphite on mount, lower left: COOLING TOWERS WOOD-STEEL
creditlinerepro: © Bernd and Hilla Becher / Sonnabend Gallery

makers.displaymaker: Bernd and Hilla Becher, German, established 1959

texts.textentryhtml: Bernd and Hilla Becher exerted an unrivaled influence on art photography in the century’s final quarter, both through their teaching at the Düsseldorf Academy and through their art. Cooling Towers Wood-Steel is typical of their work in its subject matter (industrial structures classifiable either as vast machines or as works of architecture), in its method (rigorously straight, centered, large-format renderings on high-gloss printing paper), and in the disinterested mode of inquiry suggested by the grid format, which distributes attention equally among the nine subjects at hand. The overarching topic of the Bechers’ career is large-scale vernacular design of the modern era. Their intellectual contribution to photography is the codification of "typology," an approach that analyzes the constituents of a group (whether cooling towers, train engines, or the faces of one’s friends) as exemplars of an unwritten code of familial variation.

Cooling Towers Wood-Steel is typical of this husband-and-wife duo’s work in its subject matter (industrial structures), in its method (rigorously straight, centered, large-format renderings on high-gloss printing paper), and in the disinterested mode of inquiry suggested by the grid format, which distributes attention equally among the nine subjects at hand. The overarching subject of the Bechers’ oeuvre is large-scale vernacular design of the modern era. Their intellectual contribution to photography is the establishment of the typology—a systematic study of the variations among similar subjects (whether cooling towers, train engines, or the faces of one’s friends)—as a central methodology for Conceptual art. The Bechers exerted an unrivaled influence on art photography in the final quarter of the twentieth century, through their teaching at the Düsseldorf Academy
as well as their art.
